text: Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing.
Diabetes Mellitus is a metabolic disease causing high blood sugar levels. Type 1 occurs when the body doesn't produce insulin, while Type 2 results from insulin resistance.

Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a common condition where the long-term force of the blood against your artery walls is high enough that it may eventually cause health problems, such as heart disease.
Myocardial Infarction, commonly known as a heart attack, occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked for a long enough time that muscle tissue becomes damaged.
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a group of progressive lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis.
Migraine is a severe type of headache, often characterized by a throbbing sensation on one side of the head, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound.
Arthritis is an inflammation of the joints, causing pain, swelling, and stiffness. Osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis are common forms.
Pneumonia is an infection that inflames air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing.
Stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or severely reduced, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.
Depression is a mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. It affects how you feel, think, and behave and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems.
Appendicitis is an inflammation of the appendix, a finger-shaped pouch that projects from your colon on the lower right side of your abdomen. It typically causes pain in the lower right abdomen.
Kidney Stones are hard deposits made of minerals and salt that form inside your kidneys. They can cause severe pain when passing through the urinary tract.
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) is a chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile flows back into the food pipe (esophagus), irritating the lining.
Hypothyroidism is a condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, leading to symptoms like fatigue, weight gain, and cold sensitivity.

Influenza, commonly known as the flu, is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses that infect the nose, throat, and sometimes the lungs, leading to fever, cough, sore throat, and body aches.
Metformin is an oral medication primarily used to lower blood sugar levels in people with type 2 diabetes by decreasing glucose production in the liver and improving insulin sensitivity.
Paracetamol (Acetaminophen) is a common pain reliever and fever reducer, widely used for mild to moderate pain and fever.
Amoxicillin is an antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including those of the ears, nose, throat, skin, and urinary tract.
Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve pain, reduce fever, and reduce inflammation. It's also used to prevent blood clots in cardiovascular conditions.
Salbutamol (Albuterol) is a short-acting beta-agonist bronchodilator used to relieve symptoms of asthma and COPD, such as wheezing and shortness of breath, by relaxing airway muscles.
Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas that helps control blood sugar. It's administered as a medication to people with diabetes (Type 1 and some Type 2) to manage their glucose levels.
Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. It works by relaxing blood vessels, allowing blood to flow more easily.
Ibuprofen is an NSAID used for reducing fever and treating pain or inflammation caused by many conditions such as headache, dental pain, arthritis, menstrual cramps, or minor injuries.
Atorvastatin is a statin medication used to lower 'bad' cholesterol (LDL) and triglycerides, and to raise 'good' cholesterol (HDL) levels, reducing the risk of heart disease.
Prednisone is a corticosteroid used to treat a wide variety of conditions, including allergic disorders, skin conditions, ulcerative colitis, arthritis, lupus, and breathing disorders.
Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant and neuropathic pain agent primarily used to treat neuropathic pain caused by damaged nerves, and sometimes as an adjunct for seizures.
Warfarin is an anticoagulant (blood thinner) used to treat and prevent blood clots, reducing the risk of stroke, heart attack, and other conditions.
Sertraline is an antidepressant of the SSRI class, prescribed for depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, and social anxiety disorder.
Loratadine is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose, watery eyes, and itchy throat or eyes.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic ('water pill') that prevents your body from absorbing too much salt, allowing the salt to instead be passed in your urine. It treats fluid retention (edema) in people with heart failure, liver disease, or kidney disorder.

Patient, a 55-year-old male, presented with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. ECG showed ST-segment elevation. Diagnosed with Myocardial Infarction. Administered Aspirin and Nitroglycerin.

A 30-year-old female reported chronic fatigue, unexplained weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold. Blood tests confirmed elevated TSH levels. Diagnosed with Hypothyroidism. Started on Levothyroxine replacement therapy.

45-year-old female presented with frequent urination, excessive thirst, and blurred vision for several weeks. Fasting blood glucose was 250 mg/dL. Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Commenced on Metformin.

Patient, 6-year-old child, presented with high fever, sore throat, and swollen tonsils with white spots. Rapid strep test was positive. Diagnosed with Bacterial Pharyngitis (Strep Throat). Prescribed Amoxicillin.

A 68-year-old male reported difficulty swallowing and a persistent cough, especially after meals. Endoscopy revealed irritation in the esophagus. Diagnosed with Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD). Advised Omeprazole.

Patient, a 70-year-old male, presented with confusion and lethargy following a fall. CT scan revealed a subdural hematoma. Diagnosed with Traumatic Brain Injury. Monitored in ICU, no specific medication beyond supportive care.

A 40-year-old male complained of sudden, intense pain in his big toe, which was red, swollen, and tender to touch. Uric acid levels were elevated. Diagnosed with Gout. Treated with Allopurinol for long-term management.

Patient, 18-year-old male, reported a sudden, sharp pain in his lower back radiating down his leg. MRI showed a herniated lumbar disc. Diagnosed with Sciatica. Managed with Ibuprofen and physical therapy.

A 50-year-old female presented with numbness and tingling sensations in her hands and feet, along with muscle weakness. Nerve conduction studies confirmed nerve damage. Diagnosed with Peripheral Neuropathy. Started on Gabapentin.

Patient, 22-year-old female, experienced recurrent episodes of bloating, abdominal pain, and alternating diarrhea and constipation. Colonoscopy was normal. Diagnosed with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). Advised dietary changes and symptomatic relief.

A 75-year-old male presented with a history of recurrent dizzy spells and a feeling of spinning, sometimes with nausea. ENT evaluation suggested inner ear disorder. Diagnosed with Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). Advised Brandt-Daroff exercises.
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a group of conditions that cause chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Rheumatoid Arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can also affect other body systems, such as the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels.
Gout is a common and complex form of arthritis characterized by sudden, severe attacks of pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness in the joints, often the big toe.
Osteoporosis is a condition that causes bones to become weak and brittle, so brittle that a fall or even mild stresses like bending over or coughing can cause a fracture.
Schizophrenia is a severe mental disorder in which people interpret reality abnormally. It may result in some combination of hallucinations, delusions, and extremely disordered thinking and behavior.
Cirrhosis is a late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions, such as hepatitis and chronic alcoholism.
Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, is a condition that causes dry, itchy, and inflamed skin. It's common in young children but can occur at any age.
Parkinson's Disease is a progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement, often including a tremor. Symptoms start gradually and worsen over time.
Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It attacks the protective myelin sheath that covers nerve fibers.
Anemia is a condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can make you feel tired and weak.
Dementia is a general term for a decline in mental ability severe enough to interfere with daily life, most commonly caused by Alzheimer's disease.
Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver, most commonly caused by a viral infection, but also by excessive alcohol consumption or autoimmune diseases.
Cataracts are a clouding of the normally clear lens of your eye, leading to blurred vision, glare, and difficulty seeing at night.
Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often caused by abnormally high pressure in your eye, leading to irreversible vision loss.
Tuberculosis (TB) is a serious infectious disease that mainly affects your lungs but can also affect other parts of your body, like your spine or brain.
Celiac Disease is an immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, leading to damage in the small intestine.
Fibromyalgia is a chronic disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tenderness in localized areas.

Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) is an infection in any part of your urinary system — your kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra. Most infections involve the lower urinary tract — the bladder and the urethra.
Gastroenteritis, often called stomach flu, is an inflammation of the lining of the intestines caused by a virus, bacteria, or parasites, resulting in diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps.
Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes rapid buildup of skin cells, resulting in thick, silvery scales and itchy, dry, red patches.
Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, where the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of your bones wears down over time.
Hypotension, or low blood pressure, is a condition where the blood pressure is abnormally low, leading to symptoms like dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting.
Hyperthyroidism is a condition where your thyroid gland produces too much of the thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms like rapid heartbeat, weight loss, and irritability.
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is a hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age, causing irregular periods, excess androgen, and polycystic ovaries.
Endometriosis is a disorder in which tissue similar to the lining of your uterus grows outside your uterus, often causing pain and fertility problems.
Erectile Dysfunction (ED) is the inability to get or keep an erection firm enough for sex, and is a common type of male sexual dysfunction.
Celiac Disease is an immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, leading to damage in the small intestine.
Conjunctivitis, or pinkeye, is an inflammation or infection of the transparent membrane (conjunctiva) that lines your eyelid and covers the white part of your eyeball.
Insomnia is a common sleep disorder that can make it hard to fall asleep, hard to stay asleep, or cause you to wake up too early and not be able to get back to sleep.
Obstructive Sleep Apnea is a serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep, leading to loud snoring and daytime fatigue.
Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a condition that causes an uncontrollable urge to move your legs, usually due to an uncomfortable sensation. It typically happens in the evening or nighttime hours.
Anxiety Disorder is a type of mental health condition characterized by feelings of worry, nervousness, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with daily activities.
Bipolar Disorder is a mental health condition that causes extreme mood swings that include emotional highs (mania or hypomania) and lows (depression).
Schizoaffective Disorder is a mental health condition that includes symptoms of both schizophrenia and a mood disorder, such as depression or bipolar disorder.

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a disorder in which people have recurring, unwanted thoughts, ideas, or sensations (obsessions) that make them feel driven to do something repetitively (compulsions).

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition that's triggered by a terrifying event — either experiencing it or witnessing it. Symptoms may include flashbacks, nightmares and severe anxiety.
Phobias are a type of anxiety disorder defined by a persistent and excessive fear of an object or situation. Common phobias include fear of heights, spiders, or public speaking.
Diverticulitis is an inflammation or infection of small pouches (diverticula) that can form in the colon, leading to abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and changes in bowel habits.
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a common disorder that affects the large intestine, causing symptoms like cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, or constipation.

Crohn's Disease is a type of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) that causes inflammation of your digestive tract, which can lead to abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition.

Ulcerative Colitis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that causes long-lasting inflammation and ulcers (sores) in your digestive tract, primarily affecting the innermost lining of your large intestine and rectum.
Cystic Fibrosis is an inherited disorder that causes severe damage to the lungs, digestive system, and other organs in the body due to a defective gene causing thick, sticky mucus buildup.
Lupus is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect almost any part of your body, including your joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs, with symptoms varying widely.
Polymyalgia Rheumatica is an inflammatory disorder that causes muscle pain and stiffness, usually in the shoulders and hips. It affects older adults and often occurs with giant cell arteritis.

Sciatica is pain that radiates along the path of the sciatic nerve, which branches from your lower back through your hips and buttocks and down each leg, typically affecting only one side of your body.
Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord, typically causing headache, fever, and a stiff neck.
Encephalitis is an acute inflammation of the brain, typically caused by a viral infection, leading to symptoms like fever, headache, confusion, and seizures.
Vertigo is a sensation of spinning or dizziness, often caused by inner ear problems, leading to balance issues and nausea.
Concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury caused by a blow to the head or violent shaking of the head and body, resulting in temporary brain dysfunction.
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) involves a gradual loss of kidney function over time, where kidneys are no longer able to filter waste products from the blood adequately.
Simvastatin is a statin medication prescribed to lower high cholesterol and triglyceride levels in the blood, reducing the risk of heart attacks and strokes.
Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic ('water pill') used to treat high blood pressure and fluid retention (edema) caused by various medical conditions.
Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that reduces the amount of acid produced in the stomach, used to treat heartburn, acid reflux, and ulcers.
Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat high blood pressure and chest pain (angina) by relaxing blood vessels.
Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant that treats nerve pain (neuropathic pain) and partial seizures. It works by affecting chemicals in the brain and nerves.
Tramadol is an opioid pain reliever used to treat moderate to moderately severe pain. It works in the brain to change how your body feels and responds to pain.
Cephalexin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections of the skin, ears, upper respiratory tract, bones, and urinary tract.
Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used to treat conditions such as arthritis, blood disorders, severe allergic reactions, skin diseases, certain cancers, and eye conditions.
Duloxetine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) antidepressant, also used for anxiety, diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia, and chronic musculoskeletal pain.
Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety disorders and panic disorder. It works by enhancing the activity of certain neurotransmitters in the brain.
Rosuvastatin is a statin medication used to lower high cholesterol and triglycerides, and to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events like heart attack and stroke.
Sertraline is an antidepressant of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) class, used to treat depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic attacks, and anxiety disorders.
Naproxen is an NSAID used for the relief of mild to moderate pain, inflammation, and fever, often prescribed for arthritis, menstrual cramps, and headaches.
Doxycycline is an antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including acne, urinary tract infections, intestinal infections, and certain eye infections.
Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal medication that slows the movement of the gut, decreasing the number of bowel movements.
Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including respiratory, skin, bone, joint, and urinary tract infections.
Tamsulosin is an alpha-blocker that relaxes the muscles in the prostate and bladder neck, making it easier to urinate. It's used to treat symptoms of an enlarged prostate (BPH).
Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used for the maintenance treatment of asthma and to relieve symptoms of seasonal allergies.
Fexofenadine is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy throat, or watery eyes. It is known for being non-drowsy.
Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and irregular heartbeats (arrhythmias) by affecting the strength and rhythm of heart contractions.
Levothyroxine is a synthetic thyroid hormone used to treat hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) and goiter. It replaces the hormone normally produced by your thyroid gland.
Lantus (Insulin Glargine) is a long-acting insulin used to control high blood sugar in adults and children with diabetes mellitus.
Humalog (Insulin Lispro) is a fast-acting insulin used to improve blood sugar control in adults and children with diabetes mellitus.
Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. It helps relax blood vessels and lower blood pressure.
Escitalopram is an SSRI antidepressant used to treat major depressive disorder and generalized anxiety disorder.
Venlafaxine is an SNRI antidepressant used to treat major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and social anxiety disorder.
Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet medication used to prevent heart attacks and strokes in people with heart disease, recent stroke, or peripheral artery disease.
Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure, angina, and heart failure. It also helps prevent future heart attacks.
Hydrocodone/Acetaminophen is a combination opioid pain reliever and fever reducer used to treat moderate to severe pain.
Gabapentin enacarbil (Horizant) is an extended-release form of gabapentin used to treat restless legs syndrome and neuropathic pain.
Folic Acid is a B vitamin used to treat and prevent folate deficiency anemia, and is crucial during pregnancy to prevent birth defects.
Vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin that helps your body absorb calcium and phosphorus, crucial for bone health. It is used to treat vitamin D deficiency.
Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant used to treat depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder.
Citalopram is an SSRI antidepressant used to treat depression. It works by restoring the balance of a certain natural substance (serotonin) in the brain.
Ranitidine is an H2 blocker that reduces the amount of acid produced in the stomach. It was commonly used for heartburn, acid reflux, and ulcers, though its use has declined.
Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that decreases the amount of acid produced in the stomach, used for GERD and erosive esophagitis.
Metronidazole is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial and parasitic infections, including those of the reproductive system, gastrointestinal tract, and skin.
Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections, skin infections, and certain sexually transmitted infections.
Dextromethorphan is a cough suppressant found in many over-the-counter cold and flu medications, used to relieve coughing.
Pseudoephedrine is a decongestant that narrows blood vessels in the nasal passages, used to relieve nasal congestion due to colds, allergies, and hay fever.
Cetirizine is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy watery eyes, and hives.
Loratadine is an antihistamine used for the symptomatic relief of allergy symptoms like sneezing, runny nose, itchy eyes, or hives. It is typically non-drowsy.
Naproxen Sodium is an NSAID used for pain relief from conditions like arthritis, menstrual cramps, headache, muscle aches, and fever.
Baclofen is a muscle relaxant and antispastic agent used to treat muscle spasms caused by multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, or other neurological disorders.
Tizanidine is a short-acting muscle relaxant used to treat muscle spasms, typically from spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis, or other neurological conditions.
Cyclobenzaprine is a muscle relaxant used to treat muscle spasms and pain associated with acute musculoskeletal conditions.
Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant used to treat depression and chronic nerve pain. It affects neurotransmitters in the brain.
Venlafaxine is an SNRI antidepressant used for major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and social anxiety disorder.
Bupropion is an antidepressant that also aids in smoking cessation, used for major depressive disorder, seasonal affective disorder, and to help people stop smoking.
Escitalopram is an SSRI antidepressant primarily used for major depressive disorder and generalized anxiety disorder, by increasing serotonin levels in the brain.

Patient, 68-year-old male, experienced sudden weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty speaking. Rushed to ER, CT scan confirmed ischemic stroke. Started on Aspirin and referred for rehabilitation.

A 40-year-old female reported severe, cramping abdominal pain, bloating, and alternating bouts of diarrhea and constipation over several months. Colonoscopy was clear. Diagnosed with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). Advised dietary changes.

Patient, 7-year-old male, developed a high fever, chills, and a painful cough producing yellowish phlegm. Chest X-ray showed lung consolidation. Diagnosed with Pneumonia. Treated with oral Amoxicillin.

A 60-year-old male presented with a two-month history of increasing tremor in his right hand at rest, stiffness, and slow movements. Neurological assessment confirmed a diagnosis of Parkinson's Disease. Initiated Levodopa/Carbidopa therapy.
Patient, 35-year-old female, reported severe itching and red, scaly patches on her elbows and knees that worsen during stress. Diagnosed with Psoriasis. Prescribed topical corticosteroids.

A 22-year-old female presented with extreme thirst, frequent urination, and unexplained weight loss despite increased appetite. Lab tests showed very high blood glucose. Diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes. Started on Insulin injections.

Patient, 50-year-old male, complained of persistent lower back pain radiating down his left leg, accompanied by numbness. MRI showed disc herniation. Diagnosed with Sciatica. Managed with Ibuprofen and physical therapy.

A 65-year-old male visited due to persistent cough and shortness of breath that has worsened over the past year, especially with exertion. He has a long history of smoking. Diagnosed with COPD. Prescribed Salbutamol inhaler as needed and advised smoking cessation.

Patient, 15-year-old male, presented with sudden, severe pain in his right ankle joint, which was red, swollen, and very tender. History of occasional joint pains. Diagnosed with Gout. Treated with anti-inflammatory medication.

A 38-year-old male reported a chronic feeling of sadness, loss of interest in activities, disturbed sleep, and significant weight loss for over six months. Diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder. Started on Sertraline.

Patient, 70-year-old female, experienced a dizzy spell and lightheadedness upon standing up quickly. Blood pressure was recorded as 90/60 mmHg. Diagnosed with Orthostatic Hypotension. Advised to increase fluid intake and stand up slowly.

52-year-old male, presented with increasing abdominal swelling, yellowing of skin and eyes (jaundice), and chronic fatigue. History of alcohol abuse. Diagnosed with Alcoholic Cirrhosis. Referred for liver transplant evaluation.

A 2-year-old child was brought in with widespread, itchy, red skin patches, especially in the creases of her elbows and knees. History of sensitive skin. Diagnosed with Eczema. Treated with topical emollients and mild corticosteroids.

Patient, 40-year-old female, complained of recurrent episodes of severe, one-sided throbbing headache, often accompanied by visual aura, nausea, and sensitivity to light. Diagnosed with Migraine with Aura. Prescribed Sumatriptan for acute relief.

29-year-old female, reported persistent abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and weight loss for several months. Colonoscopy showed inflammation and ulcers in the large intestine. Diagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis. Initiated Mesalamine therapy.
A 60-year-old male presented with gradual onset of difficulty seeing at night and noticing halos around lights. Eye pressure was elevated. Diagnosed with Glaucoma. Started on Latanoprost eye drops.

Patient, 10-year-old male, presented with fever, persistent cough, and night sweats. TB skin test was positive, and chest X-ray showed infiltrates. Diagnosed with Tuberculosis. Started on multi-drug anti-TB regimen.

67-year-old male, suffered a fall resulting in a painful, swollen hip. X-ray confirmed a hip fracture. Diagnosed with Osteoporosis-related Fracture. Scheduled for surgical repair and initiated Vitamin D and Calcium supplementation.

A 28-year-old female complained of irregular menstrual periods, excessive facial hair growth, and difficulty conceiving. Ultrasound showed multiple cysts on her ovaries. Diagnosed with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). Advised lifestyle modifications.

Patient, 55-year-old male, reported episodes of lightheadedness, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort during exertion. Stress test revealed blockages in coronary arteries. Diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease. Prescribed Atorvastatin and referred for angiography.
33-year-old female, presented with a butterfly-shaped rash on her face, joint pain, and extreme fatigue. Blood tests showed specific autoantibodies. Diagnosed with Lupus. Managed with Prednisone.

A 42-year-old male experienced severe, radiating abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting after a heavy meal. Lab tests showed elevated lipase and amylase. Diagnosed with Acute Pancreatitis. Admitted for pain management and IV fluids.

Patient, 60-year-old female, reported difficulty sleeping for several months, characterized by trouble falling asleep and frequent awakenings. Denied other symptoms. Diagnosed with Chronic Insomnia. Advised sleep hygiene practices and short-term Z-drug.

58-year-old male, presented with increasing forgetfulness, difficulty with daily tasks, and mood changes. Family reported progressive decline over two years. Diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease. Started on Donepezil.

A 20-year-old male presented with persistent delusions of grandeur and auditory hallucinations for several months, significantly impairing his social function. Diagnosed with Schizophrenia. Started on Risperidone.

Patient, 70-year-old male, complained of muscle pain and stiffness, particularly in his shoulders and hips, worse in the morning. Lab tests showed elevated inflammatory markers. Diagnosed with Polymyalgia Rheumatica. Treated with Prednisone.
30-year-old female, presented with episodes of extreme worry, heart palpitations, and shortness of breath that occur unpredictably. Diagnosed with Panic Disorder. Commenced on Escitalopram.

A 5-year-old child was admitted with sudden high fever, severe headache, stiff neck, and rash. Lumbar puncture confirmed bacterial infection. Diagnosed with Meningitis. Treated with intravenous Ceftriaxone.

Patient, 48-year-old female, reported chronic fatigue, joint pain, and digestive issues including bloating after eating gluten. Blood test and biopsy confirmed villous atrophy. Diagnosed with Celiac Disease. Advised strict gluten-free diet.

63-year-old male, presented with episodes of intense dizziness and a spinning sensation, often triggered by head movements. Positional tests confirmed a diagnosis of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). Advised Epley maneuver exercises.

A 25-year-old female came in with abdominal pain, fever, and nausea, followed by severe diarrhea containing blood and mucus. Stool culture indicated bacterial infection. Diagnosed with Acute Gastroenteritis. Advised oral rehydration and Loperamide for symptoms.

Patient, 50-year-old male, reported episodes of chest pressure and shortness of breath during strenuous activities, relieved by rest. Stress test indicated stable angina. Diagnosed with Angina Pectoris. Prescribed Nitroglycerin.

38-year-old female, presented with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections, characterized by painful urination and frequent urge. Urine culture confirmed E. coli. Diagnosed with Recurrent UTIs. Treated with Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole.

A 60-year-old male experienced a sudden, severe headache and weakness on one side of his body. Emergency MRI showed a brain hemorrhage. Diagnosed with Hemorrhagic Stroke. Admitted to neurocritical care.
Patient, 72-year-old female, developed increased fatigue, cold intolerance, and memory issues. Lab tests revealed low thyroid hormone. Diagnosed with Hypothyroidism. Commenced Levothyroxine.

55-year-old male, reported persistent fatigue, nausea, and general malaise. Blood tests showed elevated liver enzymes and positive viral markers. Diagnosed with Chronic Hepatitis B. Referred to a hepatologist.

A 40-year-old female presented with severe, persistent headache, stiff neck, and sensitivity to light. Lumbar puncture showed clear fluid with elevated white blood cells. Diagnosed with Viral Meningitis. Managed with supportive care.

Patient, 65-year-old male, complained of increasing difficulty hearing, especially in noisy environments, and ringing in his ears. Audiometry confirmed high-frequency hearing loss. Diagnosed with Presbycusis. Advised on hearing aids.
30-year-old female, reported frequent feelings of intense worry, restlessness, and difficulty concentrating for over six months. Diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder. Prescribed Escitalopram.
A 4-year-old child was brought in with a barking cough and noisy breathing (stridor) that worsened at night. Diagnosed with Croup. Treated with a single dose of oral Dexamethasone.
Patient, 28-year-old male, presented with episodes of sudden, severe, stabbing pain in his face, triggered by touching or chewing. Diagnosed with Trigeminal Neuralgia. Started on Carbamazepine.

60-year-old male, complained of muscle pain and stiffness, particularly in his shoulders and hips, that was worse in the morning. Inflammatory markers were elevated. Diagnosed with Polymyalgia Rheumatica. Prescribed Prednisone.

A 55-year-old female reported progressive numbness and weakness in her legs, making walking difficult. MRI showed lesions in the brain and spinal cord. Diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). Started on disease-modifying therapy.

Patient, 70-year-old male, presented with fatigue, paleness, and shortness of breath. Blood tests showed low hemoglobin. Diagnosed with Anemia. Investigated for underlying cause and started on iron supplements.

42-year-old female, experienced painful urination, frequent urges, and cloudy urine for two days. Urine culture showed significant bacterial growth. Diagnosed with Cystitis (bladder infection). Prescribed Nitrofurantoin.

A 48-year-old female reported chronic fatigue, joint pain, and digestive issues including bloating after eating gluten. Blood test and biopsy confirmed villous atrophy. Diagnosed with Celiac Disease. Advised strict gluten-free diet
author: expert

text: A 4-year-old child was brought in with a barking cough and noisy breathing (stridor) that worsened at night. Diagnosed with Croup. Treated with a single dose of oral Dexamethasone
author: expert
